subject: Re: [junit] Do You Want to Skip Test Methods?
msgSnippet: Hi Bill, This is a valuable feature to add.  We ve been using a more manual solution to simulate what you re talking about integrating. Our driving reason
messageBody:
Hi Bill,

This is a valuable feature to add. We've been using a more manual
solution to simulate what you're talking about integrating. Our driving
reason isn't listed on the blog you referenced: we often find that in
the course of Test Driven Development we'll think of a test (say a
corner case) that we don't want to forget.

We quickly moved from sticking post-it notes on the screen or writing
and commenting out (at least a stub of) the test to just writing the
test (or stub) and leaving it in place. But we had to choose between
using no asserts (and never being reminded of the unimplemented test)
and forcing failures (which can be more of a distraction than a reminder).

Our manual solution involves temporarily wrapping the body of an
unimplemented test in a conditional that can be globally toggled on/off
for all tests. It works very nicely, for a manual solution, but should
definitely be integrated into the tools.

Take care,

- Russ


Bill Venners wrote:

>Hello All,
>
>I'm curious how many JUnit users want a way to temporarily mark certain
>test methods so that the runner doesn't execute them, but reports that
>they are skipped. This is a functionality that Vladimir R. Bossicard
>provides via his JUnit Add-Ons runner, which he describes in his first
>blog post:
>
>http://www.artima.com/weblogs/viewpost.jsp?thread=4603
>
>I'm considering whether or not it makes sense to do something similar
>for SuiteRunner, and I'd like to know what JUnit users would really
>want. If you do want something like this, for what specific use cases
>do you imagine you'd use it?
>
>Thanks.
